SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Fatigue, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, tired, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He also experiences shortness of breath during exertion and slight chest cramps that resolve after about an hour. The patient has a slight cough but is unsure if it is related to a cold or seasonal changes. He has been adhering to his medications and monitoring his blood pressure at home. The patient's diet has been off due to recent home renovations and eating out more frequently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses fatigue, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Endorses slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Endorses occasional bloating.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Jugular venous distention: Appreciated to about 8 centimeters.
• Heart: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Lungs: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Lower extremities: 1+ pitting edema.

RESULTS

Chest x-ray: Fluid in the lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Congestive heart failure.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with fatigue, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath. Physical examination and chest x-ray suggest fluid retention, likely due to heart failure.
• Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. The patient should weigh himself daily and report any weight gain or worsening symptoms. Order a follow-up echocardiogram.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure appears to be well managed at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. The patient should continue to monitor and record blood pressures at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today with right knee pain after a fall from a ladder while changing a light bulb yesterday. She reports twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. The pain is located on the inside of her knee. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it has not provided significant relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Atrial fibrillation.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY

Rhinoplasty.

MEDICATIONS

Digoxin.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Right knee: Tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain with flexion and valgus stress.
• Sensation: Normal in the lower extremity.
• No calf pain.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the left knee: No fractures or dislocations. A small amount of fluid is present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female presenting with right knee pain after a fall.

Acute medial meniscus sprain/strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has tenderness over the medial meniscus area and pain with flexion and valgus stress. X-ray shows no fractures or dislocations.
• Treatment: Knee brace and crutches for the next couple of days. Follow-up in one week. If not improved, consider MRI.
• Medication: Motrin 800 mg every 6 hours with food for two weeks.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with lower back pain. The patient reports that he strained his back while lifting heavy boxes on Saturday. He experienced a popping sound and had to lie down for about an hour before the pain subsided. Since then, he has had stiffness in his lower back. He has taken Tylenol and ibuprofen for the pain and used Icy Hot, but it did not provide significant relief. He reports tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon, which has since resolved. The patient finds it difficult to find a comfortable position while sleeping.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain and stiffness.
• Neurological: Denies numbness, endorses tingling in right toes (resolved).

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic heart murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension of the back, negative straight leg raise.

RESULTS

Diabetes labs: Hemoglobin A1c is 8.

Back x-ray: Normal bony alignment, no fracture present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Back pain (lumbar strain):
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity.
   • Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy.

2. Diabetes type 2:
   • Medical Reasoning: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.
   • Follow-up: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

3. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are on the high side.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

4. Osteoarthritis:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is managing knee osteoarthritis well.
   • Plan: No further workup needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension, who presents for his annual exam. He reports a tough spring with pollen and stress from moving his daughter to college. He has been managing his depression with Prozac and has not had any incidents recently. He has been struggling with hypertension, taking Norvasc regularly during the business week but sometimes forgetting on weekends. He experiences shortness of breath with exertion during his morning runs, particularly in humid conditions. He runs 4-5 miles daily.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Depression.
Prior lobectomy.
Hypertension.

Medications
Prozac 20 mg daily.
Norvasc.

EXAMINATION

Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/80.
Heart: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
Lungs: Clear.
Lower extremity: No edema.
Sinuses: Pain to palpation.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal.

ASSESSMENT

1. Depression - well managed with Prozac.
2. Prior lobectomy - no current issues.
3. Hypertension - controlled with Norvasc.

PLAN

1. Depression: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.
2. Prior lobectomy: No further workup or follow-up with surgeon needed.
3. Hypertension: Continue Norvasc. Order echocardiogram for murmur. Monitor blood pressure and follow up with results through the patient portal.

INSTRUCTIONS

Continue current medications. Complete echocardiogram as ordered. Follow up with results through the patient portal. Call the clinic with any questions or new symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right index finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for right index finger pain. The patient reports that she was skiing over the weekend and while going over moguls, her ski strap caught on her finger, bending it back. The incident occurred on Sunday. The patient has tried ice and ibuprofen for pain management, but the pain persists, especially with movement.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right index finger pain.
Gastrointestinal: Reports recent constipation.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Constipation, treated with Miralax.
Appendectomy at age 18.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Right index finger: Tenderness over the distal phalanx and joint. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right hand: No fractures observed, everything lines up well.

ASSESSMENT

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN

1. Prescribe aluminum foam splint for the right index finger.
2. Prescribe Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for pain management, to be taken for 1 week.
3. Instruct the patient to follow up if the pain does not improve within a week.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to use the aluminum foam splint and take Motrin as prescribed. She should follow up with the clinic if her symptoms do not improve within a week.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female who presents with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. She has been experiencing fatigue, feverishness with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also reports increased anxiety and depression. The patient has been anemic since she was 13 years old and had a hysterectomy in 1996. She had a colonoscopy approximately 5-6 years ago with no significant findings. She denies having a pacemaker, defibrillator, sleep apnea, or using oxygen at night. She drinks alcohol only once or twice a year. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Iron deficiency Anemia.
Hysterectomy in 1996.

Medications
Ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily.
Vitamin B12.

FAMILY HISTORY

Not mentioned.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Normal without any significant findings.

ASSESSMENT

• Iron deficiency anemia.
• Possible internal bleeding.

PLAN

1. Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
2. Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily with orange juice for better absorption for the next 8-12 weeks. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate after 12 weeks.
3. Referral to hematologist for further evaluation and management.
4. Follow up with the clinic for any questions or worsening symptoms.

INSTRUCTIONS

Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy. Schedule an appointment with the hematologist. Follow the bowel prep instructions provided. Call the clinic with any questions or new symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Newly diagnosed pituitary lesion with worsening headaches.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 52-year-old male who presented to his primary care provider, Dr. Howard, on 3/1/21 complaining of worsening headaches over the past few months. He denied any trouble with headaches in the past. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Neurological: Reports worsening headaches, located behind the eyes, with a dull nagging ache. Denies fever, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. Reports bumping into door frames recently.
Visual: Denies any change in vision or balance. Eyes were checked in the fall.

FAMILY HISTORY

The patient was adopted and has no knowledge of any family history.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer
Marital status: Married for 25 years
Alcohol, tobacco, and drug use: None

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neurological: The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal, motor, or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities.
Visual: Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

RESULTS

MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21: The MRI reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Pituitary adenoma.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient has a benign-appearing pituitary adenoma, incidentally discovered during workup for worsening headaches. He is symptomatic with clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I explained to the patient that the only option we have is to do surgery due to the vision loss from the mass compressing the optic chiasm. I discussed the surgical approach and potential risks involved. I also informed the patient that there is a possibility of regaining vision after surgery, but there are no guarantees.
- Medical Treatment: I will refer the patient to the eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test. We will schedule the surgery for a transsphenoidal approach to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 52-year-old female who presents for a new patient visit with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. She reports experiencing chest pain and difficulty swallowing for four days in early October 2020. The chest pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and described as sharp. The pain was worse with eating. She went to the ER, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, which were normal. The patient has not had any recurrence of chest pain or difficulty swallowing since the initial episode.

Ms. Hill has a past medical history of uterine fibroids and anemia. She had her gallbladder removed several years ago. She denies any family history of gastrointestinal problems. The patient was going through a stressful job transition at the time of the chest pain episode.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen
Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No pain or tenderness in the lower abdomen.

ASSESSMENT

• Chest pain (resolved)
• Difficulty swallowing (resolved)
• Possible etiologies: GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, anxiety

PLAN

Betty Hill is a 52-year-old female who presents for a new patient visit with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. The most likely etiology of her chest pain is anxiety related to her job transition, with possible contributions from musculoskeletal etiologies. We discussed the option of performing an EGD or upper endoscopy to evaluate her esophagus and stomach, but the patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change.

INSTRUCTIONS

Return to clinic as needed for any gastrointestinal complaints or recurrence of symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The geneticist mentioned that individuals with this syndrome may have kidney anomalies. The patient's mother reports that Katherine has 8-10 wet diapers per day.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Smith-Magenis Syndrome.
Reflux.

Surgical
None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Lives with her twin sister and mother in Dallas, Georgia.

FAMILY HISTORY

9-year-old brother with autism.
No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

MEDICATIONS

None.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
Eyes: Small appearing.
Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old former 34 and 3-week-old, twin with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. Several organ systems can be affected by this chromosomal deletion syndrome. Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature. We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports slipping on stairs while doing laundry and landing on her right wrist. She has not experienced a similar injury before. Pain is severe, rated 9/10. Patient has tried ice, ace wrap, and ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success. Injury occurred yesterday morning.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Neurological: Reports tingling in fingers.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
Cardiovascular: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: Right wrist with obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. Able to make a fist but not tightly. Metacarpals intact. Bony crepitus present.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 140/70
Heart Rate: 80 bpm
Respiratory Rate: 20
Temperature: 97.2°F

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray: Positive for Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Colles' fracture.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with a right wrist injury consistent with a Colles' fracture. X-ray confirms the diagnosis.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the diagnosis and treatment plan with the patient. Explained the need for surgery and post-operative care, including bracing and physical therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Patient will be scheduled for surgery as soon as possible. In the meantime, a brace will be provided for the right wrist. Pain management with Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours. Physical therapy to be initiated a few weeks after surgery.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 1 month to assess progress and discuss the possibility of going on vacation. The patient is advised to call or follow up sooner if pain worsens or new symptoms develop.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Philip is a patient with a past medical history of hypertension who presents today with right knee pain. He reports that he slipped and fell while working on his property a week ago. He felt a pop in his knee during the fall and has been experiencing pain and swelling since then. The pain is worse with flexion and extension of the knee. He has been taking ibuprofen for pain and swelling. He rates his pain as 4/10 when moving the knee.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
• Respiratory: No shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: No abdominal pain.
• Musculoskeletal: Right knee pain and swelling.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, managed with 20 mg lisinopril.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Patient in no apparent distress.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.
• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, previously identified.
• Musculoskeletal: Right knee with pain to palpation on the medial aspect, pain with flexion and extension, edema, and effusion.

RESULTS

Right knee X-ray: No fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain:
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice a day for pain and swelling.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to ice the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times a day, and wear a knee brace for support.
   • Activity Modification: Advise the patient to elevate the leg, avoid putting weight on the affected knee, and rest for a couple of weeks.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage the patient to reduce sodium intake and improve diet.
   • Additional Testing: Refer the patient to a nutritionist for dietary guidance.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of left shoulder pain. He has been experiencing the pain for approximately three weeks and cannot recall a specific injury that may have caused it. He has been active and recently doing work in his basement, which may have contributed to the pain. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure or reaching for objects. He has difficulty lifting objects and reaching overhead. He has been taking extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours for pain management, which provides some relief but does not eliminate the pain completely.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient reports occasional aches and pains in the past, but nothing that Tylenol couldn't manage.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports taking extra strength Tylenol for pain management.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain and limited range of motion.
Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling in the arm or hand.

VITALS

Normal

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Limited active and passive range of motion in the left shoulder. Tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips.
NEURO: Sensation in the left arm is intact to light touch distally.
CV: Brisk capillary refill to less than 3 seconds.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These reveal no evidence of fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Rotator cuff tendinopathy, Left shoulder.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, his symptoms are consistent with a left shoulder rotator cuff tendinopathy. An MRI of the left shoulder will be ordered to further evaluate the shoulder. The patient will be referred to physical therapy for approximately six to eight weeks and may continue taking Tylenol for pain management. If symptoms do not improve, a steroid injection for the shoulder may be considered.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up after completing physical therapy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. She has been taking her medications regularly and monitoring her blood pressure and blood sugar levels.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain that occurs occasionally, causing the knee to give out during walking.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal:
- Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation.
- Range of Motion: No decreased range of motion.
- Special Testing: Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS
Imaging: Left knee X-ray showed no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain.
- Medical Reasoning: Suspected arthritis due to the absence of fracture or bony abnormality on X-ray.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
- Additional Testing: None at this time.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-controlled with current medication.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.

3. Type 2 diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports fasting blood sugar levels around 130.
- Medical Treatment: Continue metformin as prescribed.
- Additional Testing: Order a hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to medication.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Stage 3 non-small cell lung cancer.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports recent diagnosis of stage 3 non-small cell lung cancer with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule. Biopsy positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing pending.

TREATMENT HISTORY

Patient is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports minimal cough and sore throat.
Gastrointestinal: Reports decreased appetite but no difficulty swallowing.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Stable, oxygen saturation within normal limits.
Neck: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Bilateral crackles in lungs.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest, possibly related to radiation.
Lower Extremities: No edema.

RESULTS
Imaging

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy and radiation therapy for stage 3 non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation therapy (45 Gy). Repeat imaging after completion of radiation therapy to assess tumor response and potential for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and mild shortness of breath may be due to radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's sore throat and painful swallowing may be due to inflammation in the esophagus from radiation therapy.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow (4 times daily) to alleviate pain and improve ability to eat and drink.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up at the next scheduled visit.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A level.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes and frequent colds during the winter. No history of immune deficiencies in the family. Patient denies any recent abdominal infections or diarrhea.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking metformin for type 2 diabetes.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath or cough.
Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain or diarrhea.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.
Musculoskeletal: No issues reported.

VITALS

Weight and vitals within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: Abdomen soft, non-tender, no guarding or rebound.
Lymphatic: No lymphadenopathy.

LABS

Low immunoglobulin A level.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a low immunoglobulin A level, which is a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not report frequent infections or other symptoms that would indicate a more severe issue.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of IgA deficiency and advised the patient to monitor for any infections that do not resolve or worsen. Informed the patient to notify healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever require blood products.
- Medical Treatment: Order additional blood work to check other antibodies. Follow-up appointment after lab results.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes and is currently taking metformin.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of diet modification and monitoring blood glucose levels.
- Medical Treatment: Continue metformin and home glucose monitoring. Consider referral to a dietitian if needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient reports that the pain started about four days ago and is located on the inside of his right elbow. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The pain is rated as 6/10 and radiates slightly into his forearm. The pain has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. The patient has been engaging in pottery work during the pandemic, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain and limited range of motion.
Neurological: No numbness or tingling in the arm.
Sleep: Reports difficulty sleeping due to elbow pain.

VITALS

BP: Within normal limits.
Heart rate: Within normal limits.
Temperature: Within normal limits.
SpO2: Within normal limits.
Respiratory rate: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Positive for pain to palpation over the medial epicondyle of the right elbow. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the right wrist. No swelling or deformity noted.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality detected.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis (right elbow).

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and x-ray findings today, I have discussed with the patient the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The following treatment plan has been recommended:
1. Rest the right elbow and wear a sling while awake.
2. Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for one week.
4. Avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 1 week to evaluate the progress of his elbow pain and the effectiveness of the treatment plan. The nurse will provide the patient with a sling before leaving the clinic.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a male who presents with chest pain and shortness of breath. He has a history of hypertension and was recently in the emergency department. The patient reports falling down while walking outside and experiencing chest pain, but did not think much of it. He also reports some shortness of breath but has been managing it. The patient admits to not consistently taking his hypertension medications and not following a strict diet.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Blood pressure: 128/72
• Neck: No jugular venous distention.
• Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Lungs: Clear bilaterally.
• Lower extremities: Trace edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Congestive heart failure (CHF).
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's recent hospitalization for CHF is likely due to dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I counseled the patient on the importance of consistently taking his medications and following a proper diet.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily. Consult with a nutritionist for dietary advice. Weigh daily and call if weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of hypertension and has not been consistently taking his medications.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I advised the patient to take his medications consistently and monitor his blood pressure at home.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Order a renal artery ultrasound to rule out any underlying issues.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain below ribs.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a male patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right-sided abdominal pain below his ribs, which has been ongoing for several days. The patient reports that the pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when it occurs. He also reports dysuria and dark-colored urine. He has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father. He has taken Tylenol for the pain, but it has not been effective. He feels nauseated but has not vomited.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient has a history of kidney stones.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Not reported.

MEDICATIONS

Tylenol for pain.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and nausea.
Genitourinary: Reports dysuria and dark-colored urine.

VITALS

Normal

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdominal: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen: 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter, no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone), right ureter.

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain, alternating with Tylenol.
3. Provide a urine strainer for the patient to collect the stone when it passes.
4. Order basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks to assess progress and discuss further treatment options if necessary, such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 1-2 weeks or contact the clinic if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer on right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents with a non-healing foot ulcer on his right foot. The patient first noticed the ulcer approximately six weeks ago after wearing tight shoes. The initial blister has since become unroofed with thick, soft, and mushy skin underneath, accompanied by a foul smell and yellow drainage. The patient's primary care physician started him on antibiotics six days ago. The patient has experienced some fever and chills but no nausea or vomiting. The wound has turned black around the edges, and the patient has been experiencing cramping in his calf muscle. There is also a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is very hot.

The patient's blood sugars have been trending higher in the past few weeks, with some readings in the 300-400 range and one spike at 500-600. The patient has an A1C of 6.7 and has been well-controlled for the past two years.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Diabetes.
Diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Enjoys hiking with his wife.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Antibiotics for foot ulcer (unspecified).

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythemia, foul odor, no bony exposure.
Vascular Exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses, non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses (present via Doppler).

ASSESSMENT

Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer.

PLAN

1. Order test to check blood supply for wound.
2. Perform debridement in the office.
3. Obtain culture and consider different antibiotic therapy based on results.
4. Monitor redness and swelling in the patient's leg.
5. Schedule follow-up appointment in 7 days.
6. Encourage patient to follow up with endocrinologist to manage diabetes and maintain A1C below 7.

INSTRUCTIONS

Continue current antibiotic therapy. Await culture results for potential changes in antibiotic therapy. Follow up with endocrinologist for diabetes management. Call clinic with any additional concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a 57-year-old male who presents with a tick bite on his right knee. He noticed the bite over a week ago and reports that it has been burning and causing discomfort. He denies fever, chills, joint pain, or difficulty moving his knee. He has a history of tick bites in the past but has never been diagnosed with Lyme disease. He reports feeling generally unwell and experiencing headaches since the tick bite.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension.
Diabetes.

Surgical
None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hunting and spending time outdoors.

FAMILY HISTORY

Not reported.

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: BP 122/70, HR 67, Temp 98.4 F.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Right knee: Erythema, edema, area of fluctuance, pain to palpation, full range of motion.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite and possible Lyme disease: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for three weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm diagnosis. Monitor for response to treatment and consider IV antibiotics if necessary.

2. Hypertension: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes: Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily. Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control. Patient reports blood sugars in the 120s. Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Follow up as needed for test results and symptom management.
